isaInvestigation.title: Investigation
isaInvestigation.description: Created using the MetaboLights Online Editor (MOE)

studies.title: Liquid chromatography coupled to high-resolution mass spectrometry metabolomics: A useful tool for investigating tumor secretome based on a three-dimensional co-culture model
studies.description: Three-dimensional (3D) cell culture technologies, which more closely mimic the complex microenvironment of tissue, are being increasingly evaluated as a tool for the preclinical screening of clinically promising new molecules, and studying of tissue metabolism. Studies of metabolites released into the extracellular space (secretome) allow understanding the metabolic dynamics of tissues and changes caused by therapeutic interventions. Although quite advanced in the field of proteomics, studies on the secretome of low molecular weight metabolites (< 1500 Da) are still very scarce. We present an untargeted metabolomic protocol based on the hybrid technique of liquid chromatography coupled with high-resolution mass spectrometry for the analysis of low-molecular-weight metabolites released into the culture medium by 3D cultures and co-culture (secretome model). For that we analyzed HT-29 human colon carcinoma cells and 3T3-L1 preadipocytes in 3D-monoculture and 3D-co-culture. The putative identification of the metabolites indicated a sort of metabolites, among them arachidonic acid, glyceric acid, docosapentaenoic acid and beta-Alanine which are related to cancer and obesity. This protocol represents a possibility to list metabolites released in the extracellular environment in a comprehensive and untargeted manner, opening the way for the generation of metabolic hypotheses that will certainly contribute to the understanding of tissue metabolism, tissue-tissue interactions and metabolic responses to the most varied interventions. Moreover, it brings the potential to determine novel pathways and accurately identify biomarkers in cancer and other diseases. The metabolites indicated in our study have a close relationship with the tumor microenvironment in accordance with the literature review.

publications.title: Liquid chromatography coupled to high-resolution mass spectrometry metabolomics: A useful tool for investigating tumor secretome based on a three-dimensional co-culture model
publications.authorList: Pelosi Andrea C., Fernandes Anna Maria A. P., Maciel Leonardo F., Silva Alex A. R., Mendes Giulia C., Bueno Luísa F., Silva Lívia Maria F., Bredariol Rafael F., Santana Maycon G., Porcari Andreia M., Priolli Denise G.

protocols.name: Sample collection
protocols.description:
The presence of adipose tissue can influence the development of colorectal cancer (CRC) in vivo[1]. To better understand this influence in vitro, we used a model of human colon carcinoma (HT-29) cell line as cancer cells and pre-adipocytes cells (3T3-L1) (Banco de Células do Rio de Janeiro, BCRJ, Duque de Caxias, Brazil) as adipocytes[2]. These cell lines were cultured separately (3D-monoculture) and co-cultured (3D-co-culture), and their secretome was used to investigate the tumor microenvironment and the interaction between cancer cells and the adipocyte tissue.


2D Cell Culture

Both types of cells were thawed and then propagated in culture using Modified Dulbecco Eagle Medium (DMEM - Sigma D-5648, São Paulo, Brazil), supplemented with 100 mM sodium pyruvate (Gibco -11- 360, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, Massachusetts, USA), 10% fetal bovine serum (Gibco 2010-09, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, Massachusetts, USA) and 1% antibiotics (100 U/mL of penicillin and 10 mg/mL of streptomycin (Gibco 15140-122, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, Massachusetts, USA). Cells were cultured in a humidified chamber with 5% CO2 (HeraCELL 150) at 37 °C, incubating them with 3 mL trypsin-EDTA 0.25% (Gibco 25 200, Fisher Scientific, Waltham, Massachusetts, USA) at 37 °C for 3 min to allow cell disaggregation and propagation. DMEM plus 10% FBS was used to inactivate trypsin. The cell pellet was then transferred to a new 75 cm^2 flask (T75) containing 10 mL DMEM. Culture medium was changed according to the cell doubling time and cell viability was determined in a Neubauer chamber using Trypan Blue (Gibco 15250061, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, Massachusetts, USA).


3D Cell Culture

A Bio-Assembler system (Bio Science 662840, Greiner One Bio, Americana, Brazil) was used in the n3D Biosciences 24-well configuration[3]. The magnetic nanoparticles were prepared by removing it from the refrigerator and thawing it at room temperature 20-25 °C for about 15 min. HT- 29 cells (passage 12th) were cultured in monolayer culture in a T75 flask, with cell viability (>75%) being determined in a Neubauer chamber, when cells confluence reached 80-90%. A total of 1 µL per 10,000 cells of magnetic nanoparticles (Nanoshuttle- PL, Greiner) was added, homogenizing gently the suspension and centrifuging at 1500 rpm x 5 min, 3 times. Cells were then resuspended and each well of a cell-repellent 24-well plate was filled with an amount of solution necessary to reach 7.5 x 10^3 cells. DMEM supplemented with 100 mM sodium pyruvate, 10% fetal bovine serum and 1% antibiotics (100 U/mL of penicillin and 10 mg/mL of streptomycin) was added until a volume of 250 µL/well was reached. A magnetic coupling driver was placed under the plate for 5 h, placing it then for incubation in the humidified chamber with 5% CO2 (HeraCELL 150) at 37 °C. The plate was closed and placed and the levitation drive was place d atop the intermediate lid, to levitate the cells. The magnetic coupling drive was kept for 7 d, using the field microscopy to verify the cohesion of the structures formed. The culture medium was collected whenever the exchange was necessary using the holding drive to hold the 3D culture down while aspirating the liquid. A total of 600 µL of 3T3-L1 cells in monolayer were cultured to 90% confluence and cell viability (>75%), incubated in a supplemented medium in repellent hanging drop plate at 37 °C/5% CO2 and 95% humidity, monitoring them until the aggregates formed and differentiated to adipocytes.


3D Cell Co-Culture

3T3-L1 spheroid suspension was added in each well of cell repellent HT-29 wells plate, using a magnetic pen, 21 d after the beginning of HT-29 spheroid formation and kept for 7 d.


Refs:

[1] Jochem, C., Leitzmann, M. 2016. Obesity and Colorectal Cancer. Recent Results Cancer Res. 208:17–41. doi:10.1007/978-3-319-42542-9_2. PMID: 27909900.

[2] Zebisch, K., Voigt, V., Wabitsch, M., Brandsch, M. 2012. Protocol for effective differentiation of 3T3-L1 cells to adipocytes. Anal Biochem. 425(1):88–90. doi:10.1016/j.ab.2012.03.005. PMID: 22425542.

[3] Haisler, W.L., Timm DM, Gage, J.A., Tseng, H., Killian, T.C., Souza, GR. 2013. Three-dimensional cell culturing by magnetic levitation. Nat Protoc 8, 1940–1949. doi:10.1038/nprot.2013.125.

protocols.name: Extraction
protocols.description:
Briefly, 200 µL of the culture medium of each well were placed it into a microtube and 50 µL of iced isopropanol were added to each, keeping them overnight at -20 °C. Each sample was prepared in triplicate. Samples were then centrifuged at 12,880 x g, 4 °C for 10 min. An aliquot of 150 µL of medium of each sample was taken and dried under nitrogen. Dried extracts were resuspended with 150 µL of 200 µM p-Fluoro-DL-phenylalanine standard solution prepared in methanol:water, 1:1 v/v.


Additionally, a pooled quality control (QC) sample was prepared by pooling 20 µL of each sample in a microtube. This sample was mixed and then split it into different vials, which were subjected to the same extraction protocol described above. Blank samples (n=3) were also prepared using the culture medium without adding any cell or culture and following the complete protocol for sample preparation.

protocols.name: Chromatography
protocols.description: Chromatography analyses were performed using a Waters ACQUITY UPLC H-Class System, with an ACQUITY UPLC CSH C18 (1.7 µm, 2.1 mm x 100 mm; Waters), using water 0.1% (v/v) formic acid (A) and acetonitrile (B) as mobile phases. Segmented gradient was applied as follows: 0-2 min, 10% B; 7 min, 90% B, 7-9 min, 90% B; 9-11 min returning to 10% B, kept for 2 min 10% B for column re-equilibration, resulting in an 13 min run. Flow rate was 0.4 mL/min, column temperature 30 °C and injection volume, 5 µL for positive and 2 µL for negative mode. QC samples were used for system suitability before batch analysis and also injected after the injection of 10 samples, to investigate and filter instrumental variation.

protocols.name: Mass spectrometry
protocols.description: Mass spectrometry analysis were performed using Waters Xevo G2-XS QTof equipped with an electrospray ionization source.  Analyses were done in positive (+) and negative (-) ionization modes, using the following parameters: source temperature, 140 °C (+/-); desolvation temperature, 550 °C (+/-); desolvation flow, 900 L/h (+/-); capillary 3 kV (+) and 2.5 kV (-); sampling cone, 30 kV (+) and 40 kV (-) and cone gas flow, 10 L/h (+) and 50 L/h (-). Spectra was acquired under the acquisition mass range of 50-1200 Da, using the MSE approach (6 V for low energy and a 15-30 V ramp for high energy scanning). Leucine encephalin 200 ppm (prepared in Acetonitrile:Water, 1:1, v/v), was used as lockmass. A 0.5 mM sodium formate solution was employed for instrument calibration.

protocols.name: Data transformation
protocols.description: Raw data was processed with the Progenesis IQ software 2.4.69.11(Waters) for peak detection, alignment, integration, deconvolution, data filtering, ion annotation and MSE based putative identification of compounds. Statistical analyses were performed using the Metaboanalyst web platform (version 5.0). For the negative ionization mode data was normalized by the IS (p-Fluoro-DL-phenylalanine), log-transformed and Pareto scaled. The same procedure was used for the positive ionization mode, but the cubic transformation was applied instead of the log. Multiple volcano plot statistical tests were performed between all culture conditions and also blank samples. The relevant molecular features were ranked according to the false discovered ratio (FDR) and log2 fold change (FC) values. In the assignment of cell secretomes, only the molecular features that present FDR value < 0.05 and log2 FC > 0 when compared to the secretome of the culture medium (blank sample) were considered.

protocols.name: Metabolite identification
protocols.description: The following databases were used to suggest identifications : Lipid Maps, LipidBlast and Human Metabolome Database (HMD), considering the following parameters for identification: mass error of the precursor ≤ 5 ppm, mass error of the fragment ≤ 10 ppm, mass precision, and isotopic similarity.

assays.technologyPlatform: Liquid Chromatography MS - negative - reverse phase
Liquid Chromatography MS - positive - reverse phase
